content.question: In the short run, which of the following must be true for a perfectly competitive firm that is maximizing profits?

choices.label: The firm will shut down if it has any economic losses.
The firm will produce at the minimum of average total cost.

The firm will produce where <math alttext="M R equals M C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MR = MC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, but price from the demand curve is greater than <math alttext="M C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The firm will produce where <math alttext="M R equals M C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MR = MC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as long as <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than average variable cost.
The firm will produce the quantity that exhibits allocative and productive efficiency.

content.answer: The firm will produce where <math alttext="M R equals M C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MR = MC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as long as <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than average variable cost.
